explanations: The French source refers to 'le Soleil' (the Sun) in the context of its year-long celestial tour. The English translation renders this as 'the Sun as to the fixed Stars', explicitly adding the astronomical frame of reference (the fixed stars) against which the Sun's annual motion is observed, a detail implied in the source.

The French 'sur la Terre' (on the ground/earth), referring to where a ball rolls, is a general description. The English translation 'on a Bowling-green' explicitates this by specifying a concrete and culturally familiar setting for such an activity, making the philosopher's analogy more vivid for the English reader.

The French 'vers le but' (towards the target/goal) is a general term for the destination of the rolling ball. The English translation 'towards the Block' explicitates this by using the specific term for the target in the game of bowls, which is consistent with the preceding explicitation of 'Bowling-green'.

The French 'cela nous met dans diférens points de veüe à leur égard' (this puts us in different points of view with regard to them) explains why planets might seem irregular. The English translation 'which must make a great alteration' explicitates the *consequence* of these differing viewpoints, spelling out that they cause a significant change in perception of planetary movements.

The French 'un gros Navire' (a large ship) is a general description. The English translation 'a first rate Ship' explicitates this by employing a specific contemporary naval term for the largest and most heavily armed class of warships, thereby enhancing the illustration of mass and unwieldiness.

The French 'd'une très grande nombre de Marchandises' (a very large number of goods/merchandise) generally describes the ship's cargo. The English translation 'beside her Provisions and other Furniture' explicitates this by specifying types of cargo ('Provisions' for food/supplies, 'Furniture' for equipment) typically found on such a large vessel, clarifying the nature of its load.

The French 'notre gros Vaisseau' (our large ship) implicitly refers to the ship example previously discussed by the philosopher. The English translation 'the great Vessel I mention'd but now' makes this anaphoric reference explicit by adding 'I mention'd but now,' clearly linking it to the earlier part of the conversation.

The French 'en peril de se mouvoir' (in danger of moving) describes the Earth's potential danger generally. The English translation 'in the least danger of sinking' explicitates the specific *kind* of feared movement by using 'sinking', which clarifies the nature of the peril in the context of an Earth supported by elephants (i.e., failing and falling downwards).

The French 'pour dormir en assurance' (to sleep in safety/assurance) states the desired outcome of being secure. The English translation adds the rhetorical question 'who would sleep in Fear?', which serves to make explicit the underlying motivation—the aversion to fear—that is implicitly contrasted by the desire for 'assurance'.

The French 'à le prendre dans l'air' (taking it [the place] in the air / considering it as in the air) describes the perspective for the thought experiment somewhat impersonally. The English 'we will suppose our selves in the Air' explicitates this by clarifying the active, hypothetical agency ('we will suppose') and centering the perspective on the observers ('our selves'), making the setup of the mental exercise more direct.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P014: Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-être de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de notre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela paraîtront des Iroquois, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils pour plaire aux plus vilains Hommes du monde; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prêtre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obseur, où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumière desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, hormis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les Persans; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-être encore des rêveries.

P015: Il est assez plaisant, dit la Marquise, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairont plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien vite ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui mr paroit assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs icy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la Marquise, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliqay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-être jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espèce de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à soye tourne en même temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & même plus agitée que luy.

P016: Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la Marquise. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connaissance de tous ces petits mouvements particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.

P017: Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'être sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'aperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnaisse?
chunks.manualHtml: P008: Copernicus himself, said I, could not have comprehended it better: First then, we see some of our Neighbours passing by us, up to the Ears in Politicks, yet settling their Nation no better than we do the World in the Moon; then follows a great Sea, perhaps a Fleet of Ships, perhaps a Makrel-Boat, no matter whether; then come some of the Iroquois going to eat a Prisoner for their Breakfast, who seems as little concern'd as his Devourers: After appear the Women of the Land of Jesso, who spend all their time in dressing their Husbands Dinners and Suppers, and painting their Lips and Eye-brows blue, only to please the greatest Villains in the World: Then the fair Circassians, who are very free of their Favours, and grant all to the first Comer, except a little they reserve for their Husbands; then the Tartars going to steal Concubines for the Turks and Persians; and at last our own dear Countrymen, it may be in some points as ridiculous as the best of 'em. It is very pleasant, said the Countess, but to imagine what you tell me, tho' if I was above, and saw all this, I would have the Liberty to hasten or retard the motion of the Earth, according as the Objects pleas'd me more or less, and I assure you I should quickly send packing the Polititians and Maneaters, but should have a great curiosity for the Fair Circassians, for methinks they have a custom very particular. They are so extreamly Beautiful, said I, that their Husbands have enough, and to spare to a Stranger. I fear then, said she, the Women of our Country are very ugly, in respect of those Fair Ladies, for the Husbands part with nothing here, but keep all to themselves. 'Tis because they make more use, I reply'd, of-Hold your peace, said she, and no more of your Fooleries, I have a difficulty to clear, and you must be serious. As the Earth moves, the Air changeth every moment, so we breathe the Air of another Country: Not at all, I reply'd, for the Air which encompasseth the Earth, doth not extend above a certain height, perhaps 20 leagues it follows us and turns with us: Have you not seen the work of a Silk-Worm, the Shells which those little Animals imprison themselves in, and weave with so much Art; they are made of a Silk very close, but are covered with a Down very slack and soft: So the Earth which is solid, is covered from the surface 20 Leagues upwards, with a kind of Down, which is the Air, and all the Shell of the Silk-Worm turns at the same time: Beyond the Air is the Celestial Matter, incomparably more pure and subtile, and much more agitated than the Air: Your comparison, said, she, is somewhat mean, and yet what wonders are wrought, what Wars, what Changes in this little Shell? 'Tis true, I reply'd, but Nature takes no notice of such little particular Motions, but drives us along with the general motion, as if she were at Bouls. Methinks, said she, 'tis very ridiculous to be upon a thing that turns, and yet not be well assur'd that it doth turn; and to tell you the Truth, I begin to distrust the Reasons you give, why we should not be sensible of the Motion of the Earth; for is it possible there should not some little mark be left, by which we might perceive it?

explanations: The French "quelque Vaisseau" (some vessel) is a general term. The translation expands this by providing specific contrasting examples ("perhaps a Fleet of Ships, perhaps a Makrel-Boat"), making the potential nature and scale of the "vessel" more explicit and vivid.

The French text states the Iroquois "mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre" (will eat some prisoner of war alive). The translation adds "for their Breakfast," thereby making explicit a specific, albeit potentially sensationalized, timing or context for this act, which was not specified in the original.

The French "le Repas" (the meal) is a general term. The translation expands this into "Dinners and Suppers," making explicit the specific types of meals, adding a level of detail not present in the source.

The French phrase "ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris" (what they believe essentially belongs to their husbands) is somewhat abstract. The translation "a little they reserve for their Husbands" makes this more concrete by quantifying the reserved portion as "a little," thus explicitating the nature of what is reserved.

The French "voler des Femmes" (to steal women) is general. The translation "steal Concubines" makes explicit the intended status or role of the stolen women, clarifying information that was implied by the context but not directly stated in the source.

The French phrase "ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique" (those who involve themselves/get entangled in Politics) describes people by their activity. The translation "the Polititians" makes this explicit by assigning them a direct noun label, thus clarifying their identity or role.

The French "le Maris ne relâchent rien" (the husbands release/give up nothing) implies that they keep everything for themselves. The translation makes this implication explicit by adding "but keep all to themselves," spelling out the direct consequence of not parting with anything.

The French describes the down as "un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche" (a certain very light and very loose/slack down). The translation "with a Down very slack and soft:" adds the quality "soft," making explicit a characteristic typically associated with down that was implied by the original adjectives.

The French "jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur" (up to twenty leagues of height) implies an upward direction from the Earth's surface. The translation "20 Leagues upwards," makes this direction explicit.

The French pronoun "luy" (it/him) in the phrase "plus agitée que luy" refers anaphorically to "l'air" (the air) mentioned earlier in the sentence. The translation "much more agitated than the Air:" makes this reference explicit by restating the noun.

The French "Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables" (You present the Earth to me under very contemptible ideas) refers generally to the philosopher's portrayal. The translation "Your comparison...is somewhat mean," explicitly links the Marquise's critical reaction to the specific silkworm analogy the philosopher had just used, clarifying the direct object of her sentiment.

The French "qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation" (that such great agitation reigns on all sides) describes a general state of turmoil. The translation "what Changes" specifies a key outcome or manifestation of this "agitation," making explicit one of the significant consequences implied by widespread societal disturbance.

The French "& se joüe de la petite boule" (and plays with the little ball / makes sport of the little ball) is somewhat general about how Nature interacts with the Earth. The translation "as if she were at Bouls." makes this interaction more concrete and specific by likening Nature's action to playing the game of bowls, thus explicitating a particular manner of "playing" with the Earth.

The French "toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'aperçoive du mouvement de la Terre" (all the precautions you take to prevent one from noticing the Earth's movement) refers to the philosopher's arguments. The translation "the Reasons you give, why we should not be sensible of the Motion of the Earth;" makes explicit that these "precautions" take the form of reasons or explanations offered by the philosopher.

chunks.sourceHtml: P018: Les mouvements les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires, sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous moralisez, dit- elle, quand il est question de Physique, cela s'appelle bâiller. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en voilà assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moi avec mon Ignorance.
chunks.manualHtml: P009: All Motions, said I, the more common and Natural they are, are the less perceptible, and this holds true even in Morality; the motion of self Love is so natural to us, that for the most part we are not sensible of it, and we believe we act by other Principles: You are Moralizing, said she, to a question of Natural Philosophy: But 'tis enough for the first time, let us now go home, and meet here again to Morrow; you with your Systemes, and I with my ignorance.

explanations: The French term 'Physique', in the 17th-century context of Fontenelle's work (from the phrase 'quand il est question de Physique'), referred to the broad study of nature, equivalent to what was then termed 'Natural Philosophy'. The translation to 'of Natural Philosophy' explicitly provides this historical clarification. Instead of using the direct cognate 'Physics', which for a modern reader might imply a narrower, more specialized field, the translator chose 'Natural Philosophy' to accurately reflect the wider scope of scientific inquiry (including astronomy and cosmology) that Fontenelle was popularizing. This choice aligns with the cultural context of the Scientific Revolution, where 'Natural Philosophy' was the encompassing term for the study of the natural world.

chunks.sourceHtml: P019: En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Tycho Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fût immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planètes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planètes autour de la Terre. Mais la Marquise, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puisqu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands corps; que le Soleil n'étoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planètes tournaient autour de luy; que ce systême ne pouvoit être propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.
chunks.manualHtml: P010: In returning back to the Castle, that I might say all I could on the Subject, I told her of a third Systeme, invented by Ticho Brahe, who had fix'd the Earth in the Centre of the World, turn'd the Sun round the Earth, and the rest of the Planets round the Sun; for since the new discoveries, there was no way left to have the Planets turn round the Earth. But the Countess, who had a quick apprehension, said, she thought it was too affected, among so many great Bodies, to exempt the Earth only from turning round the Sun; that it was improper to make the Sun turn round the Earth, when all the Planets turn round the Sun; and that tho' this Systeme was to prove the immobility of the Earth, yet she thought it very improbable: So we resolv'd to stick to Copernicus, whose opinion we thought most Uniform, Probable, and Diverting.

explanations: The translator has added the word "only" to the English translation. In the French source, the idea that the Earth is being *uniquely* or *solely* exempted from turning around the Sun is implied by the subsequent justificatory clause "puisqu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands corps" (since one could not exempt so many other large bodies from it). The addition of "only" in the target text makes this implied uniqueness explicit within the description of the act of exempting the Earth, thereby spelling out a relationship (Earth as a sole exception) that was left unstated in the immediate preceding phrase.

The French source states that Copernicus's system "& n'a aucun mélange de préjugé" (and has no mixture of prejudice). This characteristic implies that the system is more rational, aligned with evidence rather than preconceived notions, and therefore more likely to be true or correct. The translator makes this implication explicit by substituting "Probable" for the description of being unprejudiced. "Probable" directly expresses an assessment of the system's likelihood of being true, a quality inferred from its freedom from prejudice mentioned in the source. This adds clarifying information about the system's perceived epistemic status that was only implied.

chunks.sourceHtml: P020: SECOND SOIR. Que la Lune est une Terre habitée.
chunks.manualHtml: P011: The Second Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P011: The Second Evening.

chunks.sourceHtml: P021: Le lendemain au matin dès que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la Marquise, j'envoyai savoir de ses nouvelles, & lui demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle etoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic lui-même. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnêteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la Marquise & moi nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la conversation ne manqua pas de tourner aussitôt sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puisque le Soleil, qui est présentement immobile, a cessé d'être Planète, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de lui, a commencé d'en être une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une folie & d'une vision. C'en est peut-être une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens parti dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des intelligences dans le party opposé, & qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mêmes. Pour moi, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, — & je me tiens toujours en état de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.
chunks.manualHtml: P012: IN the Morning, I sent to the Countess's Apartment, to know how she had rested, and whether the Motion of the Earth had not disturb'd her? she answer'd, she began to be accustom'd to it, and that she had slept as well as Copernicus himself: Soon after there came some Neighbours to dine with her, but they went away in the Evening; so that after Supper we walk'd again into the Park, and immediately fell upon our Systemes. She so well conceiv'd what I told her the night before, that she desir'd I would proceed without any repetition. Well, Madam, said I, Since the Sun, which is now immoveable, hath left off being a Planet; and the Earth, which turns round him, is now become one, you will not be surprized when you hear that the Moon is an Earth too, and that she is inhabited as ours is. I confess, said she, I have often heard talk of the World in the Moon, but I always look'd upon it as Visionary and meer Fancy. And it may be so still, said I. I am in this case as People in a Civil War, where the uncertainty of what may happen makes 'em hold intelligence with the opposite Party; for tho' I verily believe the Moon is inhabited, I live civilly vvith those who do not believe it; and I am (as some honest Gentlemen in point of Religion) still ready to embrace the prevailing Opinion, but till the Unbelievers have a more considerable Advantage, I am for the People in the Moon.

explanations: The French "en tournant" (while turning), in the context of discussing the Earth's movement, implicitly refers to the Earth's rotation. The English translation "the Motion of the Earth" makes this reference explicit by specifying both the entity ("the Earth") and the nature of its movement ("Motion"), which was only implied in the concise French phrase.

The French "il vint chez elle du monde" (some people came to her place) is translated as "there came some Neighbours to dine with her". The translator makes explicit the probable identity of "du monde" by specifying "some Neighbours" (an identity implied in a rural context) and adds the specific purpose of their visit ("to dine with her"), which was not explicitly stated in the source's description of their arrival and extended stay.

The French "Elle les avoit si bien conceus" (She had understood them so well) refers to "nos Sistêmes" (our systems) discussed previously. The English translation "She so well conceiv'd what I told her the night before" explicitly links her understanding to the specific content and timing of the previous evening's conversation ("what I told her the night before"), a connection that was implied by the narrative flow but not directly articulated in the French clause.

The French phrase "je me tiens toujours en état de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus" (I always keep myself in a position to be able to rally to their opinion with honor, if it prevailed) describes a pragmatic stance. The English translation "I am (as some honest Gentlemen in point of Religion) still ready to embrace the prevailing Opinion" incorporates the parenthetical addition "(as some honest Gentlemen in point of Religion)". This addition serves to make the nature of the narrator's pragmatism more explicit and impactful for the English reader of the late 17th century by drawing a parallel to contemporary attitudes towards religious conformity in England, an analogy not present in Fontenelle's original text but which re-writes it for cultural relevance.

The French pronoun "ils" (they) in the phrase "en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable" refers anaphorically to "ceux qui ne le croyent pas" (those who do not believe it) mentioned earlier in the paragraph. The English translation replaces this pronoun with the specific noun phrase "the Unbelievers," making the referent explicit.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P022: Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre Paris & Saint-Denis, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris, qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de Notre Dame, & voye Saint-Denis de loin; on luy demandera s'il croit que Saint-Denis soit habité comme Paris. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je vois bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint-Denis je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la vérité quand on est sur les Tours de Notre-Dame, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint-Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint-Denis ressemble fort à Paris, que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourrait bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'être habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint-Denis n'est point habité, puisqu'il n'y voit personne. Notre Saint-Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.

P023: Ah! interrompit la Marquise, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que votre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint-Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous voilà dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvements de la Terre, dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me rendent timide sur tout le reste; mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Hélas! Madame, répliquay-je, être lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy- même, & en vertu d'une nature particulière qu'il a; mais les Planètes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumière à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumière du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.

P024: Mais, dit la Marquise, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere du Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours, pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide, & retournent d'un autre côté, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette même dureté e& cette même solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'être posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. Au contraire, parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroît qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pâture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la même maniere, dit la Marquise, que quand nous sommes frapés de l'éclat des Conditions; élevées au-dessus des nôtres, & que nous ne voyons pas, qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extrêmement.

P025: C'est la même chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit être simplement spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nôtres, & qu'ils prennent notre Terre pour un Astre, sans savoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paraissons faire assez regulièrement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux; mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours eté tournée depuis; elle ne nous présente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que notre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-même, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.
chunks.manualHtml:
P013: Suppose there had never been any Communication between London and Greenwich, and a Cockney, who was never beyond the Walls of London, saw Greenwich from the top of the Pyramid; you ask him if he believes Greenwich is inhabited as London is? He presently answers, No; for, saith he, I see People at London, but none at Greenwich; nor did I ever hear of any there: 'Tis true, you tell him, that from the Pyramid he cannot perceive any Inhabitants at Greenwich, because of the distance; but all that he doth discover of Greenwich very much resembleth what he sees at London, the Steeples, Houses, Walls; so that it may very well be inhabited as London is; all this signifies nothing, my Cockney still persists Greenwich is not inhabited, because he sees no body there. The Moon is our Greenwich, and every one of us as meer Cockneys as he that never was out of the sound of Bow-Bell. You are too severe, said she, upon your Fellow-Citizens; we are not all sure so silly as your Cockney; since Greenwich is just as London is, he is a Fool if he doth not think it inhabited: But the Moon is not at all like the Earth. Have a care what you say, I reply'd, for if the Moon resembleth the Earth, you are under a necessity to believe it inhabited. If it be so, said she, I own I cannot be dispens'd from believing it, and you seem so confident of it, that I fear I must, whether I will or no. 'Tis true, the two Motions of the Earth (which I could never imagine till now) do a little stagger me as to all the rest: But yet how is it possible the Earth should enlighten as the Moon doth, without which they cannot be alike? If that be all, said I, the difference is not great, for 'tis the Sun which is the sole Fountain of Light; that Quality proceeds only from him, and if the Planets give Light to us, it is because they first receive it from the Sun; the Sun sends Light to the Moon, and she reflects it back on the Earth; the Earth in the same manner receives Light from the Sun, and sends it to the Moon; for the Distance is the same between the Earth and the Moon, as between the Moon and the Earth. But is the Earth, said the Countess, as fit to send back the Light of the Sun as the Moon is? You are altogether for the Moon, said I, she is much oblig'd to you; but you must know that Light is made up of certain little Balls, which rebound from what is solid, but pass through what admits of an entrance in a right Line, as Air or Glass: So that, that which makes the Moon enlighten us, is that she is a Firm and Solid Body, from which the little Balls rebound; and we must deny our Senses, if we will not allow the Earth the same Solidity; in short, the Difference is how we are seated, for the Moon being at so vast a Distance from us, we can only discover her to be a Body of Light, and do not perceive that she is a great Masse, altogether like the Earth: Whereas on the contrary, because we are so near the Earth, we know her to be a great Masse, but do not discover her to be a Body of Light, for want of the due distance: It is just so with us all, said the Countess, we are dazled with the Quality and Fortune of those who are above us, when, do but look to the Bottom, and we are all alike.

P014: Very true, said I, we would judge of all things, but still stand in the wrong place; we are too near to judge of our selves, and too far off to know others: So that the true way to see things as they are, is to be between the Moon and the Earth, to be purely a Spectator of this World, and not an Inhabitant. I shall never be satisfy'd, said she, for the Injustice we do the Earth, and the too favourable opinion we have of the Moon, till you assure me that the People in the Moon are as little acquainted with their Advantages, as we are with ours, and that they take our Earth for a Planet, without knowing theirs is one too. Do not doubt it, said I, we appear to them to perform very regularly our function of a Planet: 'Tis true, they do not see us make a Circle round them, but that is no great matter. That half of the Moon which was turn'd towards us at the beginning of the World, hath been turn'd towards us ever since; the Eyes, Mouth, and Face which we have fancy'd of the Spots in her, are still the same, and if the other opposite half should appear to us, we should no doubt fancy another Figure from the different Spots that are in it: Not but that the Moon turns upon her self, and in the same time that she turns round the Earth, that is in a Month; but while she is making that turn upon her self, and that she should hide a cheek for Example, and appear somewhat else to us, she makes a like part of her Circle round the Earth, and still presents to us the same Cheek; so that the Moon, who in respect of the Sun and Stars turns round her self, in respect of us doth not turn at all; they seem to her to rise and set in the space of fifteen Days; but for our Earth, it appears to her to be held up in the same place of the Heavens: 'Tis true, this apparent Immobility is not very agreeable for a Body which should pass for a Planet, but it is not altogether perfect, the Moon hath a kind of trembling, which causeth a little corner of her Face to be sometimes hid from us, and a little corner of the opposite half appears; but then upon my word, she attributes that trembling to us, and fancies that we have in the Heavens the motion of a Pendulum, which vibrates to and fro.

That half of the Moon which was turn'd towards us at the beginning of the World, hath been turn'd towards us ever since; the Eyes, Mouth, and Face which we have fancy'd of the Spots in her, are still the same, and if the other opposite half should appear to us, we should no doubt fancy another Figure from the different Spots that are in it: Not but that the Moon turns upon her self, and in the same time that she turns round the Earth, that is in a Month; but while she is making that turn upon her self, and that she should hide a cheek for Example, and appear somewhat else to us, she makes a like part of her Circle round the Earth, and still presents to us the same Cheek; so that the Moon, who in respect of the Sun and Stars turns round her self, in respect of us doth not turn at all; they seem to her to rise and set in the space of fifteen Days; but for our Earth, it appears to her to be held up in the same place of the Heavens: 'Tis true, this apparent Immobility is not very agreeable for a Body which should pass for a Planet, but it is not altogether perfect, the Moon hath a kind of trembling, which causeth a little corner of her Face to be sometimes hid from us, and a little corner of the opposite half appears; but then upon my word, she attributes that trembling to us, and fancies that we have in the Heavens the motion of a Pendulum, which vibrates to and fro.
explanations: The French 'un Bourgeois de Paris' (a citizen of Paris) is translated as 'a Cockney'. While also a localization, 'Cockney' makes explicit a specific type of naive provincialism associated with that London stereotype, which is only generally implied by 'Bourgeois de Paris'.

The French 'qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville' (who will never have left his City) is expanded to 'as he that never was out of the sound of Bow-Bell.' This makes explicit the defining characteristic of the 'Cockney' stereotype, specifying the nature of his limited experience which was more general in the source.

The French 'vous nous faites tort' (you wrong us/do us an injustice) is translated as 'You are too severe, said she, upon your Fellow-Citizens'. The addition 'upon your Fellow-Citizens' explicitly clarifies the referent of 'nous' (us), specifying that the Marquise is defending the general populace or her peers.

The French 'je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur' (I see in you an air of confidence that already scares me) is translated to 'you seem so confident of it, that I fear I must, whether I will or no.' The clause 'whether I will or no' explicitly spells out the Marquise's feeling of being reluctantly compelled to believe, a nuance only implied by 'me fait déjà peur'.

The French 'Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable.' (It is only in the Sun that this [being luminous] is a considerable quality.) is translated as 'for 'tis the Sun which is the sole Fountain of Light; that Quality proceeds only from him'. The phrase 'sole Fountain of Light' explicitly clarifies *why* the Sun's luminosity is 'considérable' by emphasizing its unique origin, information which is less direct in the source.

The French 'elle nous la renvoye' (she sends it back to us) referring to the Moon and sunlight, is translated as 'she reflects it back on the Earth'. The verb 'reflects' makes the specific scientific process of light reflection explicit, whereas 'renvoye' is more general.

The French 'il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumière du Soleil' (the Earth must also send back to the Moon the Sun's light) is translated as 'the Earth in the same manner receives Light from the Sun, and sends it to the Moon'. The addition of 'receives Light from the Sun' explicitly spells out the necessary preceding step for the Earth to illuminate the Moon, a step only implied in the source.

The French explanation of light begins 'La lumiere est composée de petites balles...'. The English translation prefaces this with 'but you must know that Light is made up of certain little Balls...'. The introductory phrase 'but you must know that' is an addition by the translator, making the pedagogical intent explicit by framing the information as something being formally imparted.

The French 'renvoye ces petites balles' (sends back these little balls) is translated as 'from which the little Balls rebound'. The word 'rebound' explicitly describes the specific mechanical action implied by the corpuscular theory of light (little balls bouncing off a solid surface), which is more general in the French 'renvoye'.

The French 'Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette même dureté e& cette même solidité.' (Now I believe that you will not dispute this same hardness and solidity of the Earth.) is translated as 'and we must deny our Senses, if we will not allow the Earth the same Solidity;'. The English version makes explicit the *reason* why the Earth's solidity is incontrovertible (it would be a denial of sensory experience), a justification that is only implied by the milder French assumption of agreement.

The French 'l'éclat des Conditions; élevées au-dessus des nôtres' (the brilliance of conditions; elevated above ours) is translated as 'the Quality and Fortune of those who are above us'. 'Quality and Fortune' explicitly specifies the socio-economic nature of the 'Conditions' that dazzle, aspects that are more abstractly implied in the French.

The French 'qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extrêmement' (that at bottom they all resemble each other extremely) is translated as 'when, do but look to the Bottom, and we are all alike.' The phrase 'we are all alike' spells out more directly and perhaps more emphatically the egalitarian implication of fundamental human similarity.

The French 'Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir.' (Who would be between the Moon and the Earth, that would be the true place to see them well.) is translated as 'So that the true way to see things as they are, is to be between the Moon and the Earth'. The addition 'to see things as they are' explicitly states the epistemological benefit or purpose of this ideal vantage point, which is implied in the French.

The French 'Astre' (celestial body/star), when referring to how the Earth might appear from the Moon, is translated as 'Planet'. This makes the specific astronomical classification explicit, aiding clarity for a popular audience in the context of Copernican astronomy.

The French 'fonctions d'Astres' (functions of celestial bodies/stars) is translated as 'function of a Planet'. Similar to the instance above, this explicitates the astronomical term to 'Planet', reinforcing the specific scientific context for the reader.

The French 'sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre' (on the basis/foundation of the spots she shows us), describing the imagined face on the Moon, is rendered as 'of the Spots in her' in the phrase 'the Eyes, Mouth, and Face which we have fancy'd of the Spots in her'. The English phrasing makes the relationship more direct by implying the spots are the material *from which* the face is imagined, rather than merely the evidence for it, thus explicitating the compositional link.

The French 'd'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure' (other differently arranged spots would doubtless make us imagine some other figure) is translated as 'we should no doubt fancy another Figure from the different Spots that are in it:'. The English construction 'from the different Spots' explicitly states the spots as the causal source or material for the imagined figure, whereas the French uses the spots as the agent (subject) of 'feroient imaginer' (would make imagine).

The French source states the Moon's synchronous rotation: 'Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-même, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois;'. The English translation, after rendering this fact, inserts a lengthy explanation: 'but while she is making that turn upon her self...it appears to her to be held up in the same place of the Heavens:'. This added passage explicitly details *how* synchronous rotation results in the same lunar face being presented to Earth and the relative perceptions of celestial movements by hypothetical Lunarians, information only implied or unstated in the French.

The French text mentions 'ce tremblement' (this trembling) of the Moon, referring to libration. The English translation explicitates this by adding a descriptive clause: 'which causeth a little corner of her Face to be sometimes hid from us, and a little corner of the opposite half appears'. This clause clarifies the visual manifestation and effect of the Moon's libration, details not provided in the source's brief mention.

chunks.sourceHtml: P026: Toutes ces Planètes, dit la Marquise, sont faites comme nous, qui rejetons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mêmes. La Terre dit: Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, _Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je, il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Représentez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous savez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vitesse après qu'elle a été donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre côté, de même la lumière s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a été réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumière blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumière même du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lorsqu'elle étoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumière éclatante que nous recevons du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus être qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour; & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la manière dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumière pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, étant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans être veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voilà le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Décours pour elles.
chunks.manualHtml: P015: I find, saith the Countess, the Planets are just like us; we cast that upon others which is in our selves; the Earth saith, 'Tis not I that turn, 'tis the Sun; the Moon saith, 'tis not I that shake, 'tis the Earth; there is a great deal of errour every where. But I would not advise you, said I, to undertake the reforming it; you had better convince your self of the entire resemblance of the Earth and the Moon: Imagine then these two great Bowls held up in the Heavens, you know that the Sun always enlightens the one half of a Body that is round, and the other half is in the Shadow; there is then one half of the Earth and one half of the Moon which is enlightned by the Sun; that is, which hath Day, and the other half which is Night. Observe also, that as a Ball hath less force after it hath been struck against a Wall which sends it to the other side, so Light is weakned when it is reflected. This pale Light which comes to us from the Moon, is the very Light of the Sun, but it cannot come to us from the Moon but by reflection; it hath lost much of the Force and Lustre it had when it came directly from the Sun upon the Moon; and that bright Light which shines directly upon us from the Sun, and which the Earth reflects upon the Moon, is as pale and weak when it arrives there; so that the Light which appears to us in the Moon, and which enlightens our Nights, is the parts of the Moon which have Day, and that part of the Earth which hath Day, when it is opposite to the part of the Moon which hath Night, gives Light to it: All depends upon how the Moon and the Earth behold one another. At the beginning of the Month we do not see the Moon, because she is between the Sun and us; that half of her which hath Day, is then turn'd towards the Sun, and that half which hath Night, turn'd towards us; we cannot see it then, because it hath no Light upon it; but that half of the Moon which hath Night, being turn'd to the half of the Earth which hath Day, sees us without being perceiv'd, and we then appear to them just as the full Moon doth to us; so that, as I may say, the People of the Moon have then a full Earth; but the Moon being advanc'd upon her Circle of a Month, comes from under the Sun, and begins to turn towards us a little corner of the half which is Light, there's the Crescent; then those parts of the Moon which have Night do not see all the half of the Earth which hath Day, and we are then in the Wayn to them.

explanations: The French 'ne doit plus être qu'une lumiere blanchâtre' (must no longer be but a whitish light) describes the resulting color of the reflected light. The English 'is as pale and weak' explicitly adds the characteristic 'weak', making the implied diminished intensity of the light (previously mentioned as having 'lost much of the Force and Lustre') an explicit part of its description alongside 'pale'.

The French 'lors qu'elles sont tournées vers' (when they are turned towards/facing) describes a general orientation necessary for illumination. The English 'when it is opposite to' specifies a more precise geometric alignment (implying a direct 180-degree opposition), thereby making the optimal condition for such illumination more explicit than the broader French term.

The French sentence 'Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumière pour se faire voir' states that we do not see the Moon's dark half, with the relative clause 'qui n'a aucune lumière pour se faire voir' (which has no light to make itself visible) implicitly providing the reason. The English translation 'we cannot see it then, because it hath no Light upon it;' makes this causal relationship explicit by using the conjunction 'because'.

The French phrase '& nous voit sous la même figure...' (and [the Moon's dark side] sees us in the same form...) implies an observer on the Moon through the verb 'nous voit' (sees us). The English '& we then appear to them...' makes this implied observer explicit with the pronoun 'them,' clarifying that the Earth appears this way to the hypothetical inhabitants of the Moon.

The French sentence starting with 'C'est alors...' (It is then... / At that point...) describes a situation resulting from previous conditions. The English translation introduces the corresponding clause with 'so that, as I may say...', framing it explicitly as a consequence or result of the preceding astronomical explanation, thereby spelling out the logical connection more overtly.

chunks.sourceHtml: P027: Il n'en faut pas davantage, dit brusquement la Marquise, je saurai tout le reste quand il me plaira, je n'ai qu'à y penser un moment, & qu'à promener la Lune sur son Cercle d'un mois. Je vois en gennral que dans la Lune ils ont un mois à rebours du nôtre, & je gage que quand nous avons pleine Lune, c'est que toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune est tournée vers toute la moitié obscure de la Terre; qu'alors ils ne nous voyent point du tout, & qu'ils comtent Nouvelle Terre. Je ne voudrois pas qu'il me fût reproché de m'être fait expliquer tout au long une chose si aisée. Mais les Eclipses, comment vont-elles? Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner, répondis-je. Quand la Lune est Nouvelle, qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & que toute sa moitié obscure est tournée vers nous qui avons le jour, vous voyez bien que l'ombre de cette moitié obscure se jette vers nous. Si la Lune est justement sous le Soleil, cette ombre nous le cache, & en même temps noircit une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui etoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune. Voilà donc une Eclipse de Soleil pour nous pendant notre jour, & une Eclipse de Terre pour la Lune pendant sa nuit. Lors que la Lune est pleine, la Terre est entre elle & le Soleil, & toute la moitié obscure de la Terre est tournée vers toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune. L'ombre de la Terre se jette donc vers la Lune; si elle tombe sur le Corps de la Lune, elle noircit cette moitié lumineuse que nous voyons, & à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour, elle luy dérobe le Soleil. Voilà donc une Eclipse de Lune pour nous pendant notre nuit, & une Eclipse de Soleil pour la Lune pendant le jour dont elle joüissait. Ce qui fait qu'il n'arrive pas des Eclipses toutes les fois que la Lune est entre le Soleil & la Terre, ou la Terre entre le Soleil & la Lune, c'est que souvent ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite, & que par consequent celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse, jette son ombre un peu à côté de celuy qui en devroit être couvert.
chunks.manualHtml: P016: I comprehend you very well, said the Countess, the People in the Moon have a Month quite contrary to us; when we have a full Moon, their half of the Moon which is light, is turn'd to our half of the Earth which is dark; they do not see us at all, and they have then a new Earth, this is plain. But now tell me how come the Eclipses? You may easily guess that, said I, when it is new Moon, that she is between the Sun and us, and all her dark half is turn'd towards us who have Light, that obscure shadow is cast upon us, if the Moon be directly under the Sun, that shadow hides him from us, and at the same time obscures a part of that half of the Earth which is light, which was seen by that half of the Moon which was dark, here then is an Eclipse of the Sun to us during our Day, and an Eclipse of the Earth to the Moon during her Night. When it is full Moon, the Earth is between her and the Sun, and all the dark half of the Earth is turn'd towards all the light half of the Moon; the shadow then of the Earth casts it self towards the Moon, and if it falls on the Moon, it obscures that light half which we see, which hath then Day, and hinders the Sun from shining on it: Here then is an Eclipse of the Moon to us during our Night, and an Eclipse of the Sun to the Moon during her Day: But the reason that we have not Eclipses every time that the Moon is between the Sun and the Earth, or the Earth between the Sun and the Moon, is, because these three Bodies are not exactly plac'd in a right Line, and by Consequence that that should make the Eclipse, casts its shadow a little beside that which should be obscur'd.

explanations: The French phrase "Il n'en faut pas davantage" (literally "No more is needed of it" or "That's enough") implies the Marquise has understood enough to deduce the rest. The translation "I comprehend you very well" makes this implicit understanding explicit and direct, stating her comprehension rather than relying on implication.

The translator adds "this is plain." after the Marquise's statement translated as "they have then a new Earth" (from "qu'ils comtent Nouvelle Terre."). This addition explicitly articulates the clarity or obviousness of the deduction, which is only implied by the Marquise's confident tone and reasoning in the source text.

The French phrase "Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner" (meaning "It is up to you to guess it" or "You only have to guess it") is translated as "You may easily guess that". The addition of the adverb "easily" makes explicit the facility of the task, which is implied in the original context but not overtly stated.

The French "elle luy dérobe le Soleil" (literally "it [the Earth's shadow] steals the Sun from it [the Moon's luminous half]") uses the metaphorical verb "dérober" (to steal). The translation "hinders the Sun from shining on it" makes the physical mechanism explicit, clarifying that the shadow blocks sunlight rather than metaphorically 'stealing' the Sun.

The French phrase "Ce qui fait que..." (literally "That which makes it that..." or "What causes it that...") introduces an explanation. The English translation "But the reason that..." explicitly frames the subsequent clause as providing "the reason", making the logical function more overt. The addition of "But" also enhances the explicit connection to the preceding discourse.

chunks.sourceHtml: P028: Je suis fort étonnée, dit la Marquise, qu'il y ait si peu de mystere aux Eclipses, & que tout le monde n'en devine pas la cause. Ah! vraiment, répondis-je, il y a bien des Peuples qui de la maniere dont ils s'y prennent, ne la devineroient encore de longtemps. Dans toutes les Indes Orientales, on croit que quand le Soleil & la Lune s'éclipsent, c'est qu'un certain Demon qui a les Griffes fort noires, les étend sur ces Astres dont il veut se saisir; & vous voyez pendant ce temps-là les Rivières couvertes de Têtes d'Indiens qui se sont mis dans l'eau jusqu'au cou, parce que c'est une situation tres propre à obtenir du Soleil & de la Lune qu'ils se défendent bien contre le Demon. En Amérique, on etoit persuadé que le Soleil & la Lune etoient fâchéz quand ils s'éclipsoient, & Dieu sait ce qu'on ne faisoit pas pour se raccommoder avec eux. Mais les Grecs qui etoient si raffinez, n'ont-ils pas creu long-temps que la Lune étoit ensorcelée, & que des Magiciennes la faisoient descendre du Ciel pour jeter sur les Herbes une certaine écume malfaisante? Mais nous, n'eûmes-nous pas belle peur il n'y guere plus de trente ans, à une certaine Eclipse de Soleil, qui arriva? Une infinité de Gens ne se tinrent-ils pas enfermez dans des caves, & les Philosophes qui écrivent pour nous rassurer, n'écrivirent ils pas en vain?
chunks.manualHtml: P017: I am surpriz'd, said the Countess, that there should be so little mystery in Eclipses, and that the whole World should not know the Cause of 'em. Nor never will, said I, as some People go about it. In the East Indies, when the Sun and the Moon are in Eclipse, they believe a certain Devil who hath black Claws is seising on those Planets with his Talons, and during that time the Rivers are cover'd with the Heads of Indians, who are up to the Neck in Water, because they esteem it a very devout Posture, to implore the Sun and the Moon to defend themselves against the Devil. In America they are persuaded that the Sun and the Moon, when Eclipsed, are angry, and what is it they will not do to be reconciled with them? The Greeks, who were so refin'd, did they not believe the Moon was enchanted, and that the Magicians forc'd her to descend from Heaven, and shed a dangerous juice on the Plants? Nay, in what a pannick Fear were we in above thirty years ago at an Eclipse of the Sun? How many People hid themselves in their Cellars, and all the Philosophers of Gresham could not perswade them to come out till the Eclipse was over?

explanations: The French "les étend sur ces Astres" (spreads them [his claws] over these celestial bodies), in the context of "dont il veut se saisir" (which he wants to seize), describes a general action. The English "is seising on those Planets with his Talons" makes the demon's action more explicit by using a more direct verb "seising on" (instead of "spreads over") and by restating the instrument as "his Talons" (after "Claws" were mentioned), thus emphasizing the aggressive nature and means of the attack, which was more generally implied.

The French "une situation tres propre à obtenir" (a very suitable situation to obtain/get) is general. The English "a very devout Posture, to implore" explicitates this by: 1) changing "situation" to the more concrete "Posture" and specifying its nature as "devout," adding a religious characteristic to "propre" (suitable) that was not explicit. 2) changing the neutral "obtenir" (to obtain/get) to "implore," specifying the method of seeking divine intervention as an earnest plea. These changes make the nature of the Indians' ritual action more specific.

The French "belle peur" is an idiomatic expression for "a big fright" or "a good scare." The English "pannick Fear" explicitates the intensity and specific nature of this fear by characterizing it as "panic," a sudden, overwhelming, and potentially irrational terror. This is a more specific psychological interpretation than the general implication of intense fear in "belle peur."

The French "les Philosophes qui écrivent pour nous rassurer" (the Philosophers who write to reassure us) is a general reference. The English translation "all the Philosophers of Gresham" makes this specific by adding "of Gresham," likely localizing the reference for an English audience by invoking a known British scientific institution and adding information not present in the source. Furthermore, the French "n'écrivirent ils pas en vain?" (didn't they write in vain?) describes a general failure. The translation "could not perswade them to come out till the Eclipse was over?" explicitates the specific consequence and manifestation of this failure, detailing the exact outcome of their futile efforts and thus expanding on the original, more general statement.

chunks.sourceHtml: P029: En vérité, reprit-elle, tout cela est trop honteux pour les hommes, il devrait y avoir un Arrêt du Genre humain, qui défendît qu'on parlât jamais d'Eclipses, de peur que l'on ne conserve la memoire des sotises qui ont été faites ou dites sur ce Chapitre là. Il faudrait donc, répliquai-je, que le même Arrêt abolît la memoire de toutes choses, & défendît qu'on parlât jamais de rien, car je ne sache rien au monde qui ne soit le monument de quelque sotise des hommes.
chunks.manualHtml: P018: Methinks, said she, 'tis scandalous for Men to be such Cowards; there ought to be a general Law of Mankind to prohibit the discoursing of Eclipses, that we might not call to mind the Follies that have been said and done upon that Subject. Your Law then, said I, must abolish even the Memory of all things, and forbid us to speak at all, for I know nothing in the World which is not a Monument of the Folly of Man.
chunks.aiHtml: P018: Methinks, said she, 'tis scandalous for Men to be such Cowards; there ought to be a general Law of Mankind to prohibit the discoursing of Eclipses, that we might not call to mind the Follies that have been said and done upon that Subject. Your Law then, said I, must abolish even the Memory of all things, and forbid us to speak at all, for I know nothing in the World which is not a Monument of the Folly of Man.
explanations: The French "trop honteux pour les hommes" (too shameful for men) describes the previously mentioned foolish reactions to eclipses as shameful for mankind. The English translation "'tis scandalous for Men to be such Cowards" makes the implicit cause of this shame (fear leading to foolishness) explicit by directly labelling men as "Cowards." This adds an explicit character judgment not directly stated in the original, which focused on the actions being shameful.

The French "un Arrêt du Genre humain" (a decree/ruling of Humankind) implies a directive of universal scope. The translation "a general Law of Mankind" makes this implied universality explicit by adding the adjective "general" to "Law," thereby specifying the comprehensive nature of the proposed edict.

The French "le même Arrêt" (the same decree) anaphorically refers to the decree just proposed by the Marquise. The English translation "Your Law" makes this referential link explicit by using a possessive pronoun ("Your"), directly attributing the proposed law to the Marquise and spelling out the connection.

The French "abolît la memoire de toutes choses" (abolish the memory of all things) already suggests a complete eradication of memory. The English translation "abolish even the Memory of all things" introduces the intensifier "even," which explicitly underscores the all-encompassing and extreme nature of the philosopher's suggestion, thereby heightening the rhetorical impact that was more subtly conveyed in the source.

The French "quelque sotise des hommes" means "some folly/foolishness of men," referring to individual or multiple instances of foolish acts. The English translation "the Folly of Man" (with capitalization) transforms this into a singular, abstract concept of "Folly" as an inherent, essential attribute of "Man" as a collective. This re-writing generalizes and makes explicit a philosophical interpretation of human nature that is less direct in the original's phrasing.

chunks.sourceHtml: P030: Dites-moi, je vous prie, une chose, dit la Marquise. Ont-ils autant de peur des Eclipses dans la Lune, que nous en avons ici? Il me paraîtroit tout-à-fait burlesque, que les Indiens de ce pays-là se missent à l'eau comme les nôtres; que les Amériquains crussent notre Terre fâchée contre eux; que les Grecs s'imaginassent que nous fussions ensorcelez; que nous allassions gâter leurs Herbes, & qu'enfin nous leur rendissions la consternation qu'ils causent icy-bas. Je n'en doute nullement, répondis-je. Je voudrais bien savoir pourquoy Messieurs de la Lune auroient l'esprit plus fort que nous. De quel droit nous feront-ils peur sans que nous leur en fassions? Je croirois même, ajoûtai-je en riant, que comme un nombre prodigieux d'hommes ont été assez fous, & le sont encore assez pour adorer la Lune, il y a des Gens dans la Lune qui adorent aussi la Terre, & que nous sommes à genoux les uns devant les autres. Aprés cela, dit-elle, nous pouvons bien prétendre à envoyer des influences à la Lune, & à donner des crises à ses Malades, mais comme il ne faut qu'un peu d'esprit & d'habileté dans les Gens de ce Pays-là, pour détruire tous ces honneurs dont nous nous flattons, j'avoüe que je crains toûjours que nous n'ayons quelque desavantage.
chunks.manualHtml: P019: But what do you think, said she, of the People in the Moon, are they as afraid of an Eclipse as we are? It would be very burlesque for the Indians there to be up to the Neck in Water; that the Americans should believe the Earth angry with them; the Greeks fancy we were bewitch'd, and would destroy their Plants; in short, that we should cause the same Consternation among them, as they do here. And why not, said I? I do not doubt it at all; for why should the People of the Moon have more Wit than we? What right have they to affright us, and not we them? For my part, I believe that since a prodigious company of Men have been and still are such Fools to adore the Moon, there are People in the Moon that worship the Earth, and that we are upon our knees the one to the other. But sure, said she, we don't pretend to send any Influences to the Moon, and to give a Crisis to her sick; if the People have any Wit in those Parts, they will soon destroy the Honour we flatter our selves with, and I fear, we shall have the disadvantage.

explanations: The French pronoun 'ils' (they), subject of 'Ont-ils...dans la Lune' (Are they...in the Moon), implicitly refers to the inhabitants of the Moon. The English translation makes this referent explicit by introducing the noun phrase 'the People' within the larger phrase 'of the People in the Moon', clearly identifying the group being discussed before the subsequent pronoun 'they' is used.

The French 'se missent à l'eau' (literally 'put themselves in the water' or 'got into the water') describes a general action. The English translation 'to be up to the Neck in Water' adds the specific detail 'up to the Neck,' which is not explicitly stated in the source, thus making the description of the immersion more vivid and detailed by adding clarifying information.

The French 'Je n'en doute nullement' (I do not doubt it at all) is a firm statement of agreement. The English translation adds the phrase 'And why not,' before rendering the core meaning (which follows as 'I do not doubt it at all'). This addition makes explicit a rhetorical stance of immediate, almost challenging, affirmation or obviousness that was only implicitly suggested by the directness of the French phrase.

The French 'Messieurs de la Lune' (literally 'Gentlemen of the Moon') could carry a slightly ironic or formal tone, or be interpreted as referring primarily to males. The English 'the People of the Moon' makes it explicit that the reference is to all inhabitants generally, neutralizing potential gender or class connotations and clarifying the scope of 'Messieurs' to be more inclusive, which aligns with the work's aim to popularize science for a broad audience.

The French 'un nombre prodigieux d'hommes' (a prodigious number of men) is translated as 'a prodigious company of Men.' The word 'company' is more specific than 'nombre' (number), explicitly emphasizing the men as a collective group or assembly, rather than just a large quantity. This spells out a relationship (of being a collective) that was less pronounced in the original.

The French 'Aprés cela' (After that / Following that) indicates a general sequential or logical progression. The English 'But sure' makes the specific rhetorical function more explicit: 'sure' often signals a concession, while 'But' introduces a contrasting point. This combination spells out a complex argumentative connection that was less specifically defined in the source.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P031: Ne craignez rien, répondis-je, il n'y a pas d'apparence que nous soyons la seule sotte espèce de l'Univers. L'ignorance est quelque chose de bien propre à être generalement répanduë, & quoy que je ne fasse que deviner celle des Gens de la Lune, je n'en doute non plus que des Nouvelles les plus seures qui nous viennent de là.

P032: Et quelles sont ces Nouvelles seures? interrompit-elle. Ce sont celles, répondis- je, qui nous en sont apportées par ces Savants qui y voyagent tous les jours avec des Lunettes de longue veuë. Ils vous diront qu'ils y ont découvert des Terres, des Mers, des Lacs, de très hautes Montagnes, des Abîmes très profonds.
chunks.manualHtml: P020: Fear it not Madam, said I; do you think we are the only Fools of the Universe? Is it not consistent with Ignorance to spread it self every where? 'Tis true, we can only guess at the Folly of the People in the Moon, but I no more doubt it, than I do the most authentick News that comes from thence. What News comes from thence, said she? That which the Learned bring us, I reply'd, who travel thither every day with their Tubes and Tellescopes: they will tell you of their Discoveries there, of Lands, Seas, Lakes, high Mountains, and deep Abysses.
