explanations: The source uses the personification "les Planetes s'entre-considèrent" (the Planets look at/consider each other) to imply mutual observation between worlds. The target translation makes the implied agents of this observation explicit by naming them "the Astronomers of both Planets" and describes their action more concretely as "levelling their Tubes at one another," thereby replacing Fontenelle's figurative language with a more direct and specific depiction.

The source's "leurs Christophe Colombs" (their Christopher Columbuses) uses a metaphorical plural to signify great explorers. The target translation explicitates this by providing specific examples, "Sir Francis Drake and Columbus," adding a culturally relevant English figure to clarify the type of explorers implied by Fontenelle.

The source states humanity is "punis" (punished) by the "grands travaux" (great labors) of astronomy, implying these difficulties contradict Nature's intent to "épargner la peine" (spare the trouble), as mentioned earlier in the text. The target translation makes this implicit counter-intention explicit by stating that astronomy was made "much more difficult than Nature design'd it," directly articulating that the complexity was not part of Nature's original plan.

chunks.sourceHtml: P077: Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, répliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraîchement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nôtres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
chunks.manualHtml: P059: If there are sixteen Planets, says she, Saturn must have five Moons. 'Tis very true, said I, and two of these five, are but lately discover'd; but there is somewhat that is more remarkable, since his Year is thirty of ours, there are consequently in him some Countreys, where their Night is fifteen years long; and what can you imagine Nature hath invented to give light, during so dreadful a Night? Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons, but she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.

Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons, but she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.
explanations: The French noun phrase "l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete" (literally, "the shadow of the Body of this Planet") implies the origin of the shadow. The English translation "the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts" makes this origin explicit by adding the active verb "casts" and restructuring it as a relative clause, thereby specifying the action of the planet producing the shadow. This spells out a relationship that was left unstated in the original.

The French "hors de l'ombre" (outside the shadow), used in the phrase "êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre" (being high enough to be outside the shadow), is translated as part of "being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow". The English phrase "beyond the reach of" makes explicit the implication in the French – that the ring's height ensures the shadow cannot extend to it. This adds clarifying information about the functional consequence of the ring's positioning more directly than the simpler positional statement "outside of".

The French "les lieux qui ne le voyent point" (the places that do not see it [the Sun]) is impersonal, referring to the locations themselves. The English translation "on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all" introduces "they", explicitly referencing the (potential) inhabitants of Saturn. This adds clarifying information by specifying who is affected by the lack of sunlight, a detail only implied in the original French phrase but consistent with Fontenelle's broader theme of life on other worlds.

chunks.sourceHtml: P078: En verité, dit la Marquise, de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroît bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Etres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas êté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à Vénus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mêmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a point de Lune. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas. Vous avez veu des Phosphores, de ces matières liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. Peut-être Mars a-t-il de grands Rochers fort élevés, qui sont des Phosphores naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumière qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'allumer de toutes parts dé que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous savez encore qu'il y a en Amérique des Oiseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que savons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous côtés, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?
chunks.manualHtml: P060: I protest, says the Countess, this is very surprizing, and yet all is contriv'd in such great order, that it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider the necessities of all animate Beings, and that the disposing of these Moons was not a work of Chance, for they are only divided among those Planets which are farthest distant from the Sun, the Earth, Jupiter, Saturn; indeed it was not worth while to give any to Mercury or Venus, they have too much light already; and they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day. But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none, tho' he is much further than the Earth from the Sun. It is very true, said I; no doubt but he hath other helps, tho' we do not know 'em: You have seen the Phosphorus, both liquid and dry, how it receives and imbibes the rays of the Sun, and what a great light it will cast in a dark Place: Perhaps Mars hath many great high Rocks, which are so many natural Phosphorus's, which in the day take in a certain provision of light, and return it again at night. What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant when the Sun is down to see those lighted Rocks, like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night? Besides, there is a kind of Bird in America, that yields such a light, you may read by it in the darkest night; and who knows but Mars may have great flocks of these Birds, that as soon as it is night, disperse themselves into all parts, and spread from their wings another day.

explanations: The French phrase `de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement` (with the air of a person withdrawing into herself with astonishment) describes the Marquise's manner, indicating her surprise through a narrator's observation. The English translation makes this surprise explicit by incorporating it directly into the Countess's dialogue as the utterance `this is very surprizing`.

The French `a eu en veüe` (had in view/considered) is expanded to `took time to consider`, making the deliberative aspect of Nature's process more explicit. Furthermore, `quelques Etres vivans` (some living beings) is rendered as `all animate Beings`, explicitly broadening the scope of Nature's consideration from 'some' to 'all' relevant beings.

The French states that their nights are very short (`dont les nuits sont fort courtes`) and subsequently that they count these nights as blessings (`& qui les comptent...`). The English translation makes the implied causal link between the shortness of the nights and their being valued explicit by inserting the parenthetical clarifying phrase `(as short as they are)` when stating the nights are accounted a blessing.

The French text has the Marquise making an observation: `il me semble que Mars... n'a point de Lune` (it seems to me that Mars... has no moon). This implies puzzlement. The English translation makes this implied query explicit by rephrasing her realization as a direct question: `why has not Mars a Moon too?`.

The French `des ressources` (resources) refers to means by which Mars might illuminate its nights. The English translation uses `other helps`. The addition of 'other' makes explicit the implied idea that these 'helps' are alternatives to the moons previously discussed, a contrast clear from context but not explicitly stated in the French term.

The French `la lumiere du Soleil` (sunlight) is translated as `the rays of the Sun`. Specifying 'rays' makes the mechanism of light absorption by phosphorus slightly more concrete and 'scientific' in tone for a popularizing work, thereby making an implicit characteristic of light (its ray-like nature in this interaction) explicit.

The French `des illuminations magnifiques` (magnificent illuminations) is made more concrete and culturally specific in English by likening them to `so many Illuminations at a Birth day night`. This simile provides a familiar example of grand illuminations for the contemporary English reader, making a specific type or image of magnificence explicit through cultural analogy, while the original French emphasized their naturalness (`sans aucun art`), which is omitted in this part of the English rendering.

The French `un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux` (a large number of these birds) is translated as `great flocks of these Birds`. While 'a large number' might imply birds gathering, 'flocks' explicitly describes them as organized groups, making the imagery of the birds more specific by clarifying their collective behavior.

The French `vont répandre un nouveau jour` (go and spread a new day/light) describes the effect of the luminous birds. The English translation adds the detail `from their wings` (`spread from their wings another day`), specifying a means by which the light is spread. This detail is not present in the source text and makes explicit a potential, vivid mechanism for the light dispersal.

chunks.sourceHtml: P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.
chunks.manualHtml: P061: I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the Vortex of Saturn? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.

explanations: The French phrase "c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes" (it's a sign that moons are needed/necessary) makes a general statement about the necessity of moons. The English translation specifies this by adding "in Mars" ("'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars,"), explicitly linking the general observation to Mars, a specific point of concern for the Marquise. This spells out a connection that is only implied to be made in the subsequent sentence in the source text.

The French text "si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable" (if Mars had not come to make a disagreeable exception) expresses a regret about Mars being an exception. The English translation transforms this into an explicit rhetorical question, "why should Mars only be excepted?", thereby spelling out the unstated inquiry or frustration that the Marquise implicitly feels about this exception.

The French exclamation "vraiment" (indeed, truly) serves as an intensifier for the philosopher's assertion. The English translation, within the phrase "Ah, Madam, said I," replaces "vraiment" with the vocative "Madam." This addition makes the direct address to the Marquise explicit at this specific point of interjection, clarifying the immediate recipient of the philosopher's remark, which was only implied by the broader conversational context in the French.

The French "ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout" describes leaving something aside due to despairing of success. The English translation rephrases this as a direct piece of advice: "those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end:". This makes explicit the pragmatic reason for abandoning problematic elements (i.e., "if ever you intend to make an end"), a motivation which is only implied in the French emphasis on 'despair'.

The French "& ne parlons point de luy" (and let's not speak of him [Mars]) serves to close the discussion on Mars. The English translation expands this by adding "but return to Saturn," explicitly stating the next topic of conversation and thereby guiding the dialogue's progression, a transition that was left implicit in the French.

The French "Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir" (We would be very astonished, if we were in Saturn, to see) introduces the description of Saturn's ring through a conditional statement about a shared hypothetical experience. The English translation changes this rhetorical strategy to a direct question posed to the Marquise: "What do you think of", thus making the philosopher's attempt to engage her and solicit her opinion more explicit.

The French phrase "à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment" (to send them everywhere quite boldly) refers to sending "Habitans" (inhabitants), as implied from the preceding dialogue. The English translation "I could almost send Colonies every where;" makes this more specific by using the word "Colonies." This addition clarifies the nature of populating other worlds by likening it to organized settlement, adding a layer of concrete imagery not explicitly present in the French.

The French "mais quelle lumiere," (but what light!) is a rhetorical exclamation that implies the poor quality of the light from Saturn's ring. The English translation makes this implication explicit by stating directly, "but it must be a very poor one,", thus clearly spelling out the inferred characteristic of the light.

The French text describes a hypothetical scenario: "si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids... vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud" (if you put them in our coldest countries... you would see them sweat profusely and expire from heat), implying an extreme temperature difference makes Earth's cold lethal to Saturnians. The English translation makes this comparison explicit and more vivid by stating "Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet,". This directly frames Greenland as intensely hot relative to Saturn, using the specific term "Bagnio" to articulate the severity of the heat that was only described by its effects in French, and spelling out the comparative relationship with "in comparison of that Planet".

chunks.sourceHtml:
P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.

P081: Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..
chunks.manualHtml: P062: You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew.

It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew.
explanations: The French 'me gele' (freezes me / chills me) describes a sensation or state. The English 'makes me shake with cold' explicates this by adding a specific physical reaction or symptom associated with being extremely cold. This adds a layer of descriptive detail about the Marquise's physical response and the idea's effect on her, which was only implied by the more general verb in the source.

The French 'vous m'échauffiez' (you were warming me / exciting me) suggests a general increase in temperature or excitement. The English translation 'puts me into a feaver' explicates and intensifies this sensation by specifying it as a more extreme, physiological state of high excitement or agitation. This re-writing makes the Marquise's reaction more vivid and dramatic than the more general term used in the source.

The French 'trop badin & trop folâtre' (too playful/joking and too frolicsome/light-hearted) describes the Saturnians' view of Cato as insufficiently serious. The English translation 'a merry Andrew' re-writes this judgment by making the Saturnians perceive Cato as a specific type of buffoon or clown. This explicitation introduces a concrete, culturally specific English archetype not present in the French, significantly intensifying the criticism and altering the nuance from Cato being merely 'too lighthearted' by Saturnian standards to being considered an outright fool.

chunks.sourceHtml: P082: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lents. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nôtre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extrémitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractère fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.
chunks.manualHtml: P063: It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.

Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.
explanations: The French "Il me vient une pensée" (A thought comes to me) is a neutral expression of a thought occurring. The English "It is odd to consider" adds an explicit evaluative layer, framing the Marquise's impending speculation or its consideration as "odd" or unusual. This makes explicit a potential societal perception of the unconventional nature of the topics discussed, a nuance only implicitly present in the original phrasing within its historical context.

The French "sont lents" (are slow) attributes a specific quality to Saturn's inhabitants. The English "quite contrary" goes beyond describing them as merely slow; it explicitly defines their nature in direct, heightened opposition to the previously mentioned lively inhabitants of Mercury. While the source implies a contrast through juxtaposition, the target spells out this oppositional relationship emphatically.

The French "icy" (here) refers to the speakers' current location on Earth. The English "at home" renders this specific location with a more domestic and familiar connotation, explicitly grounding the abstract discussion in a relatable context implied by the garden setting of the dialogues but not conveyed with the same nuance by the simple deictic "icy".

The French statement describes the convenience of being present ("d'être icy") where one can see other worlds in summary ("on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé"). This implicitly suggests that travel to these other worlds for such an overview is not required. The English translation makes this unstated consequence explicit by introducing the main clause "we need not travel" as the rendering of the French idea about convenience.

chunks.sourceHtml: P083: Du moins, reprit la Marquise, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nôtre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grâce à la Nature d'être Homme, & non pas Bête, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moi je veux luy rendre grâce d'être sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grâce d'être jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vôtre Tourbillon, ou de la température de vôtre Pays.
chunks.manualHtml: P064: I am sure, says the Countess, we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is not so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Jupiter or Saturn; and our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess either of Heat or Cold. I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.

I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.
explanations: The French phrase "un endroit de la Terre," meaning "a place on Earth," is general. However, the context "nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre" (we are precisely in a place on Earth) implies that the speaker (the Marquise) refers to her own specific, temperate, and favored location (implicitly France in the original). The English translation "our Country" makes this implied specificity and the speaker's proprietary connection to the location explicit by using the possessive "our" and specifying the nature of the place as a "Country." This instance of explicitation also functions as re-writing, as it aligns the location with the anglicized persona of the speaker (the Countess, presumed English by the target audience through other adaptive changes in the translation).

chunks.sourceHtml: P084: Mon Dieu! répliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a été donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considérables, un goût qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, répliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu jusqu'icy.
chunks.manualHtml: P065: Pray Sir, says she, let me give thanks for all things, to the very Vortex in which I am planted: Our proportion of Happiness is so very small, that we should lose none, but improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing, tho' never so common or inconsiderable. If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.

If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.
explanations: The French exclamation "Mon Dieu!" (My God!) is translated as "Pray Sir,". The addition of "Sir" makes explicit the addressee (the philosopher) at the very beginning of the Marquise's utterance. While the addressee is clear from the context in French, the English translation spells out this direct address immediately. This re-writes the interjection into a polite, direct address, altering the initial tone and making the act of addressing explicit.

The French "de moy" (of me), a simple self-reference by the philosopher, is translated as "an humble Servant of your Ladyships." This elaborate phrase makes explicit a social positioning of deference and humility from the philosopher towards the Marquise, a convention perhaps expected in the English socio-cultural context of the translation. This detailed social relationship was not explicitly stated in the original's simple pronoun.

The Marquise's French request, "mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux" (but ensure that Philosophy always provides me with new pleasures), shows her desire for ongoing novel philosophical enjoyment. The English translation modifies her sentiment by adding the conditional phrase "while it diverts innocently, but no longer." This makes explicit a set of conditions—innocence and limited duration—for her acceptance of philosophy as a pleasure. These qualifications are not present in the French and re-write her attitude to be more cautious or socially circumspect.

The French phrase "un goût qui les mette à profit" (a taste that puts them to use/profit) describes a disposition for appreciating common things. The English translation "improve continually what we have" rephrases this by making explicit an active and ongoing process of enhancement ("improve continually"). This changes the focus from possessing a "taste" to performing an action of continuous betterment, thereby explicating a specific, more dynamic interpretation of how one should "mettre à profit" (profit from/make use of) these things.

The French philosopher directly asks the Marquise for a promise using the phrase "Vous me promettez donc...?" (So you promise me...?). The English translation changes this direct, interrogative request for a promise into a declarative statement beginning with "I wish...". This makes the philosopher's underlying desire for her commitment explicit in the form of a wish, rather than being an implication within a direct question. This re-writes the illocutionary force from a challenge or demand to a softer expression of hope.

chunks.sourceHtml: P085: CINQUIEME SOIR. Que les étoiles fixes sont autant de Soleils, dont chacun éclaire un monde.
chunks.manualHtml: P066: The Fifth Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P066: The Fifth Evening.

chunks.sourceHtml: P086:. La Marquise sentit une vraye impatience de savoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sauroient être moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuë, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumière, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de cinquante millions de lieuë; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette même distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voilà donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.
chunks.manualHtml: P067: THE Countess was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars; are they inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or are they not inhabited? What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of fifty millions of leagues; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.

What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of fifty millions of leagues; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.
explanations: The French phrase "& on ne prend pas la peine de la compter" (and one does not take the trouble to count/calculate it) implies that the distance is so vast that its calculation relative to other solar system distances is considered not worth the effort or exceedingly complex. The English translation "it is almost beyond Arithmetick" makes this implication explicit by stating the reason: the sheer magnitude of the distance challenges the limits of arithmetic or comprehension, thus clarifying the implied difficulty or futility of calculation.

The French "elles nous la renvoyassent à cette même distance" (they would send it back to us at this same distance) describes the hypothetical return of light over the same path as part of the reflection process. The English translation "for it comes back again as far to us;" makes explicit the underlying reasoning for the doubled effective distance by stating the return journey of light as a factual mechanism. This spells out the implied physics of reflection and light travel more directly.

The French "& fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë" (and [light] having travelled two times fifty million leagues) presents a multiplication concerning the distance light would travel. The English translation "so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass" makes this explicit by: (a) explaining the rationale for the doubling ("forwards and backwards"), which was implied by the context of reflection, and (b) providing the calculated result ("an hundred millions of leagues"). This expands the condensed mathematical expression and clarifies the total path length for the reflected light.

The French "Les voilà donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes" (So there they are, luminous by themselves) states a conclusion about the inherent state of the stars. The English translation, referring to the light of a fixed star, states "which cannot but proceed from it self". This makes explicit the logical deduction that if the stars' light is not reflected (as argued previously), it must originate from the stars themselves. It clarifies the mechanism of self-luminosity (light originating from the object) as the direct consequence of the preceding argument, spelling out the connection more directly than the French statement about the stars' state.

chunks.sourceHtml: P087: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nôtre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Notre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis- je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé..
chunks.manualHtml: P068: I perceive, says the Countess, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
chunks.aiHtml: P068: I perceive, says the Countess, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
explanations: The French text, within the Marquise's reported anticipation of the philosopher's words ('M'allez-vous dire: ...'), presents 'Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils...' as a direct statement forming the basis of her subsequent questions. The English translation introduces 'if' before this statement, explicitly framing it as a conditional premise for the question 'why may not every fix'd Star...'. This explicitation spells out the logical relationship (premise for a deductive question) more directly than the French juxtaposition of statement and question.

The French pronoun 'elle' (her/it) refers to 'chaque Etoile Fixe' (each fixed star) mentioned earlier in the Marquise's question. The English translation replaces the pronoun with the full noun phrase 'the fix'd Star,' explicitly restating the antecedent. This disambiguation clarifies the reference, making the implicit connection explicit for immediate understanding.

The philosopher's response in French employs a literary allusion to Racine's *Phèdre*: 'C'est toi qui l'as nommé.' (It is you who named him/it). This quotation implicitly conveys that the Marquise has correctly articulated the idea the philosopher was leading her towards. The English translation omits this culturally specific allusion and instead provides a direct statement of its implied meaning: 'You have said it... and I will not contradict you.' This makes the philosopher's affirmation and confirmation explicit, ensuring clarity for an audience potentially unfamiliar with the French theatrical reference, thereby altering the rhetorical style but preserving the core communicative intent.

chunks.sourceHtml: P088: Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sais plus où je suis, je ne suis plus rien. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-être aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes & Tout cet espace immense qui comprend notre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes?. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moi, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le ciel n'étoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles êtoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte, en la partageant en mille & mille Tourbillons, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & assurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous côtés les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde..
chunks.manualHtml: P069: You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me; what is it all to be divided into heaps confusedly, one among another? Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? I protest it is dreadful. Dreadful, Madam, said I; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably more magnificent than it was before. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.

Dreadful, Madam, said I; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably more magnificent than it was before. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.
explanations: The French "je ne suis plus rien." (I am nothing anymore) expresses an existential state. The English "what will become of me;" makes explicit a future-oriented concern and question that is an anxious implication of feeling like "nothing," thereby spelling out this unstated emotional consequence.

The French phrase "Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante." (That confuses me, troubles me, frightens me) lists strong emotional reactions. The English translation "I protest it is dreadful." makes explicit the *speech act* of expressing these feelings by adding "I protest," which frames the Marquise's utterance as a more formal or forceful declaration of her dismay, a nuance not explicitly stated in the French.

The English translation adds "Madam," an explicit term of address. This makes explicit the formal social relationship and polite discourse between the philosopher and the Marquise, which is implied by the context and social norms of the 17th century but not verbally specified at this point in the French dialogue.

The French "je m'y sentois comme oppressé;" (I felt oppressed in it) describes a general feeling. The English "I was almost stifled for want of Air;" adds clarifying information by making explicit the specific *cause and nature* of this oppression – a feeling of suffocation due to the perceived lack of space in a small universe – which was only implied.

The French "toute une autre magnificence." (a whole other/different magnificence) implies a comparison to a previous state. The English translation "incomparably more magnificent than it was before." spells out this connection by explicitly stating the term of comparison ("than it was before"), making the contrast with the former, smaller view of the universe clear.

The French "rien épargné" (spared nothing), part of a larger clause, is general. The English "spar'd no cost" adds clarifying information by specifying "cost" as the type of thing Nature did not spare, making the abstract idea of Nature's boundless investment in creation more concrete.

The French "elle a fait une profusion des richesses" (she [Nature] made a profusion of riches) presents this as a distinct action. The English translation "even to profuseness," which modifies the preceding "spar'd no cost," recasts this relationship by making explicit that the profusion is the *degree or manner* of Nature's unstinting creation, thus spelling out a direct consequential link.

The French "à se representer" means to imagine or picture in one's mind, a mental conception. The English "as to see" makes the experience more explicitly sensory and direct, emphasizing the visual aspect (even if a mental visualization), thereby adding a layer of clarification about the mode of perception.

The French "le milieu" (the middle/center), used in context with the plural "Tourbillons" (Vortices), implies a distributive singular (the center of each vortex). The English "several centres" explicitly clarifies this by stating the plurality of centers, one for each of the multiple vortices.

The French "un Soleil" (a Sun) in the context of multiple vortices implies one sun per vortex. The English "a particular Sun" adds clarifying information by using "particular" to explicitly emphasize the distinct, individual, and specific nature of the Sun belonging to each vortex.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P089: Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de notre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; aprés eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les aperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous êtes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis & Nous mêmes, à qui la même expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. Assurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoît pas les Tourbillons.. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondrai: Ah! si vous saviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'êtoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fût dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?). mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eût êté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eût pas pu conquerir. A plus forte raison lui eût-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eût connus en ce temps-là; c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon votre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.

P090: C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle, en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez- moi franchement, votre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-même comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien tôt aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De même accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-même il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroît, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroît point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empêche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune êtoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nôtre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous êtes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grâce. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nôtre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.
chunks.manualHtml: P070: You present me with a kind of Perspective of so vast a length, that no Eye can reach to the end of it: I plainly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and you have made me discover those that dwell in the Moon, and in other Planets of our Vortex; but these indeed I do not see so clearly as those of the Earth; after these, we come to the Inhabitants of the Planets which are in other Vortex's, but they are sunk into so great a depth, that tho' I do all I can to see them, yet I must confess I can hardly perceive 'em; by the expression you use in speaking of 'em, they seem to be almost annihilated; you ought then to call 'em the Inhabitants of one of those innumerable Vortex's: We our selves, for whom the same expression serves, must confess, that we scarce know where we are, in the midst of so many Worlds; for my own part, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that I believe from henceforth, I shall never be concern'd at all for any thing: That we so eagerly desire to make our selves great, that we are always designing, always troubling and harassing our selves, is certainly because we are ignorant what these Vortex's are; but now I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness, and when any one reproaches me with my carelessness, I will answer, Ah did you but know what the fix'd Stars are! It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know what they were; for a certain Author who maintains that the Moon is inhabited, very gravely tells us, that Aristotle, (from whom no truth could be long conceal'd) must necessarily be of an opinion, back'd with so much reason; but yet he would never acquaint Alexander with the secret, fearing he might run mad with despair, when he knew there was another World, which he could not conquer; with much more reason then was this mystery of Vortex's, and fix'd Stars kept secret in Alexander's time; for tho' they had been known in those days, yet a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander; it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince; for my part, I that know 'em, am not a little troubled to find my self not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em; the most they can do, according to your way of reasoning, is but to cure People of their ambition, and their unquiet restless humour, which are diseases I am not at all troubled with; I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper, and I am confident, the Vortex's can never cure it: what if the other Worlds render ours so very little? they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth; their value is still the same, in spite of all the Worlds that can possibly exist.

explanations: The French "vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler" (you would almost no longer be able to distinguish us) describes the philosopher's difficulty in singling out humanity. The English "we scarce know where we are" translates this into an explicit statement of existential disorientation experienced by "we our selves," a consequence that was only implied in the original by the difficulty of being distinguished.

The French "se donne tant de peine" (gives oneself so much trouble/effort) is translated to "always troubling and harassing our selves". The English translation explicitly details the nature of the "peine" (trouble/effort) as active "troubling and harassing," making the self-inflicted negative aspect more vivid and explicit than the general "se donner de la peine."

The French "ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres" (my laziness profits/benefits from my new insights) is rendered as "my new lights will in part justifie my laziness." The verb "profite" (profits/benefits) is interpreted and made explicit as "justifie" (justify), clarifying that the new insights provide a rationale or excuse for her laziness, a specific mechanism of benefit that was only implied in the general term "profite."

The French rhetorical question "(comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?)" (how could a truth have escaped Aristotle?) implies Aristotle's vast knowledge. The English translation "(from whom no truth could be long conceal'd)" makes this implication an explicit affirmative statement about Aristotle's capability to know truths, removing the interrogative and speculative nuance and directly stating what was implied.

The French "qui eût êté au despoir" (who would have been in despair) is translated as "he might run mad with despair." The English translation intensifies "despair" by adding "run mad with," explicitly detailing an extreme psychological consequence (madness) of the despair, a level of intensity that was only implied by the context in the source.

The French "c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler." (it would have been to curry favor very poorly to speak to him of it) uses an idiomatic expression implying a foolish action. The English translation "a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander;" explicitly states the negative judgment of such a person as "a great Fool," making the implied characterization of the actor explicit.

The French text refers generally to "Alexandre" (Alexander) within the anecdote. The English translation, when referring to Alexander in the same context, uses the phrase "that ambitious Prince." While Alexander's ambition is historically known and contextually implied by his narrated reactions, the translator makes this defining trait explicit by adding the descriptive epithet, directly linking his character to the reason for discretion.

The French "tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay." (to draw utility/benefit from the knowledge I have of it) uses "utilité" (utility/benefit) as a general term. The English translation "not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em;" specifies the *type* of utility as intellectual gain or wisdom ("wiser"), making explicit the particular kind of benefit the philosopher might have expected, which was only implied in the broader term "utilité."

The French "l'inquietude" (restlessness, anxiety, worry) is translated as "their unquiet restless humour." The English translation expands the single noun into a more descriptive phrase, explicitly detailing the nature of the "inquietude" as an "unquiet restless humour." This elaboration makes the psychological state more vivid and specific, potentially adding a period-specific nuance with "humour," which was less detailed in the single French word.

The French "Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau" (A little weakness for what is beautiful) is translated as "I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful". The English version expands "Un peu de foiblesse" into a more emphatic admission ("I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness") and explicitly defines the "foiblesse pour" (weakness for) as "to be in love with," specifying the nature and intensity of the feeling as romantic love, which was more general and understated in the original.

chunks.sourceHtml: P091: Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nôtre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nôtre, qui n'y paroît que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est-à-dire des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, notre Terre, par exemple, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont uniques en leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?
chunks.manualHtml: P071: This Love, reply'd the Countess, smiling, is a strange thing; let the World go how 'twill, 'tis never in danger; there is no System can do it any harm. But tell me freely, is your System true? Pray conceal nothing from me; I will keep your secret very faithfully; it seems to have for its foundation, but a slight probability; which is, that if a fix'd Star be in it self a luminous Body, like the Sun, then by consequence, it must as the Sun is, be the Centre and Soul of a World; and have its Planets turning round about it: But is there an absolute necessity it must be so? Madam, said I, since we are in the humour of mingling amorous Follies with our most serious Discourses, I must tell you, that in Love and the Mathematicks People reason alike: Allow never so little to a Lover, yet presently after you must grant him more; nay more and more, which will at last go a great way: In like manner, grant but a Mathematician one little Principle, he immediately draws a consequence from it, to which you must necessarily assent; and from this consequence another, till he leads you so far (whether you will or no) that you have much ado to believe him. These two sorts of People, Lovers and Mathematicians, will always take more than you give 'em. You grant that when two things are like one another in all those things that appear to you, it is possible they may be like one another in those things that are not visible, if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise: Now this way of arguing have I made use of. The Moon, say I, is inhabited, because she is like the Earth; and the other Planets are inhabited, because they are like the Moon; I find the fix'd Stars to be like our Sun, therefore I attribute to them what is proper to that: You are now gone too far to be able to retreat, therefore you must go forward with a good grace. But, says the Countess, if you build upon this resemblance or likeness which is between our Sun and the fix'd Stars, then, to the People of another great Vortex, our Sun must appear no bigger than a small fix'd Star, and can be seen only when 'tis Night with them. Without doubt, Madam, said I, it must be so: Our Sun is much nearer to us, than the Suns of other Vortex's, and therefore its Light makes a much greater impression on our Eyes, than theirs do: We see nothing but the light of our own Sun, and when we see that, it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light: but in another great Vortex, there is another Sun, which rules and governs, and, in its turn, extinguisheth the light of our Sun, which is never seen there, but in the Night, with the rest of the other Suns, that is the fix'd Stars; with them our Sun is fastned to the great arched roof of Heaven, where it makes a part of some Bear or Bull: For the Planets which turn round about it, (our Earth for Example) as they are not seen at so vast a distance, so no body doth so much as dream of 'em: All the Suns then are Day Suns in their own Vortex's, but Night Suns in other Vortex's: In his own World or Sphere every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen; but every where else, they serve only to make a number. May not the Worlds, reply'd the Countess, notwithstanding this great resemblance between 'em, differ in a thousand other things; for tho' they may be alike in one particular, they may differ infinitely in others.

explanations: The French pronoun "luy" (him/it), referring to the Sun (from the phrase "Nous ne voyons donc que luy"), is translated and explicitated as "the light of our own Sun." This specification clarifies that the discussion pertains specifically to the Sun's light rather than the Sun as a more general celestial body, adding a layer of precision that was implicit in the original.

The concise French expression "il efface tout" (it erases everything) is expanded in the English translation. The general term "tout" (everything) is specified as "any other light," clarifying the objects being obscured. Furthermore, the verb "efface" (erases/blots out) is elaborated with the descriptive phrase "darkens and hinders us from seeing," which explains the mechanism of obscuration, making the implicit process explicit.

The single French verb "domine" (dominates/prevails, from "un autre Soleil qui y domine") is rendered by the English verbal phrase "rules and governs." This expansion into a doublet clarifies the nature of the Sun's powerful influence within its vortex by specifying distinct but related actions, making the implied aspects of its dominance explicit.

The French possessive pronoun "le nôtre" (ours), which refers implicitly to "notre Soleil" (our Sun) from the context of "il efface à son tour le nôtre," is explicitated in the translation as "the light of our Sun." This specification, similar to the first instance, clarifies that it is particularly the Sun's light that is affected, making explicit an aspect that was only implied by the pronoun.

The French object pronoun "l'" (it), referring to "notre [Soleil]" (our Sun) from the preceding context in the phrase "On l'attache avec elles," is replaced by its explicit referent "our Sun" in the translation "with them our Sun is fastned." This directly resolves the pronominal reference within the text, making the subject explicitly clear whereas it was pronominally implied in the source.

The French phrase "leur Monde" (their World), from "Dans leur Monde," is translated as "his own World or Sphere." The addition of "or Sphere" explicitates a key concept from Cartesian cosmology, which Fontenelle is popularizing. In this context, "Monde" often refers to a Cartesian vortex, conceived as a spherical system. The term "Sphere" makes this specific scientific interpretation explicit, which was only implied by the more general term "Monde."

The French phrase "ils sont uniques en leur espece" (they are unique in their kind/species) is translated and expanded to "every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen." This expansion clarifies the meaning of "uniques en leur espece" in this astronomical context by explaining *how* each Sun is unique within its system – specifically, by being the sole, visible dominant star. The original implies this uniqueness, while the translation spells out its manifestation.

The French term "cette égalité" (this equality/similarity) is translated as "this great resemblance between 'em." The word "égalité" implies a comparison or relation. The addition of "between 'em" makes this relational aspect (a resemblance *between* the worlds or suns) explicit. The intensifier "great" also adds a degree of emphasis not strictly present in "égalité."

The French phrase "un fond de ressemblance" (a basis/foundation of resemblance) is interpreted and rephrased in the translation as "tho' they may be alike in one particular." The abstract term "fond" (basis, foundation) is made more concrete by specifying that the resemblance lies "in one particular" aspect. This offers a specific interpretation of the nature of the underlying similarity, making explicit a possible way to understand this "fond" from which infinite differences can then arise.

chunks.sourceHtml: P092: Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que say-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour de Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extrémitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vide. Je ne doute pas même qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'êtant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.
chunks.manualHtml: P072: It is certainly true, said I; but the difficulty is to know wherein they differ. One Vortex hath many Planets that turn round about its Sun; another Vortex hath but a few: In one Vortex, there are inferiour or less Planets, which turn about those that are greater; in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets; here, all the Planets are got round about their Sun, in form of a little Squadron; beyond which, is a great void space, which reacheth to the neighbouring Vortex's: In another place, the Planets take their course towards the out side of their Vortex, and leave the middle void. There may be Vortex's also quite void, without any Planets at all; others may have their Sun not exactly in their Centre; and that Sun may so move, as to carry its Planets along with it: others may have Planets which in regard of their Sun, ascend and descend, according to the change of their Equilibration, which keeps them suspended. But I think I have said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Vortex.
